This document series has four parts:
1. 	 Planning for Developing Child Friendly Aanganwadis - for Officers, Administrators and Planners
2. 	 Developing Child-Friendly Aanganwadi with BaLA - Construction manual for Implementing agencies and
     Engineers
3. 	 Using effectively Child-friendly, BaLA-based Aanganwadi Environment - a user’s manual for Aanganwadi
	 Supervisors and Workers (only in Hindi)
4.	 Designing Child-friendly Aanganwadi with BaLA- for Architects and Engineers

2.	What can be Transformed in an Aanganwadi?
    To achieve quality in ICDS goals for Aanganwadis, the system of running, the activities to be per-
    formed and the physical environment—needs to be modified as per case specific situations.
    Transformation of some existing Aanganwadis of Chhattisgarh has been shown here. It is integrated
    with BaLA (Building as Learning Aid) which is based on overall development of children.

This transformation took place in Aanganwadis situated in the State capital and also in distant small town and a remote
village. Some basic ideas and processes are at the core, but they are appropriated for the different contexts. This
transformation was made possible in existing Aanganwadis as a result of coordinated and planned effort and partnership of
various entities: due to the initiative of the State Department and its stakeholders; due to motivation, contribution, creativity
and innovation brought in by the government system and the institutions outside; due to the responsibility taken by NGOs.
In other words, a positive transformation in Aanganwadis is possible and there are different ways to do it.



What can be Transformed in an Aanganwadi?                                                                                       17

                                                                              for writing and drawing. Its performance lies in
   ldsA mnkgj.k ds fy,] fp=k cukus@fy[kus dh lknh lrg cukukA                  obtaining that precise balance between roughness
   bldh ekud&izn'kZu {kerk bldh lrg esa fpdusiu&[kqjnqjsiu                    and smoothness that allows chalk to be used neatly
   dk og larqyu gS ftlls pkWd ls fy[krs le; liQkbZ vkSj vklkuh                and with convenience such that its consumption is
   lknh lrg cukukA bldh ekud&izn'kZu {kerk bldh lrg esa                       also minimised in use. To obtain this performance
   fpdusiu&[kqjnqjs iu dk og larqyu gS ftlls pkWd ls fy[krs                   standard, specification in one situation could be
   le; liQkbZ vkSj vklkuh ls fy[kk tk lds vkSj pkd Hkh de                     of using fine sand, of using fine stone dust in the
                                                                              second and in the third situation, of using lime. All
   [kpZ gksA ;g ekud&izn'kZu {kerk gkfly djus ds fy, bl lrg                   are three different building materials, but to achieve
   ds fuekZ.k ds fofunsZ'k esa ,d ifjfLFkfr ds fy, eghu jsr mi;qDr            the performance standard, there has to be flexibility
   gksxh] rks dgha nwljs esa iRFkj dh eghu /wy rks rhljs esa pwus dk          in the specification that is being used. Architect and
   mi;ksxA rhuksa gh fuekZ.k lkexzh fHkUu gSa] ij tks ekud&izn'kZu            Engineer will require incorporating this flexibility in
   {kerk pkfg,] og vyx&vyx ifjfLFkfr;ksa esa Hkh lkexzh ds                    the design and construction process.
   mi;ksx ds yphysiu ds lkFk ykbZ tk ldrh gSA okLrqdkj vkSj

		 ^ckyk*] ;kuh vaxzst+h esa fcfYMax ,t+ yfuaZx ,sM (Building as           		 BaLA is an acronym for Building as Learning Aid.

   ds lalk/u ds :i esaA bl ifjdYiuk esa lewps vk¡xuokM+h                      BaLA is to develop settings and resources for play

   ^ckyk&txgsa* vUnj ;k ckgj dgha Hkh gks ldrh gSa] tSls dejs esa]            Settings' can be inside or outside – anywhere – e.g.

   ijNh esa] cjkens esa] vk¡xu esa ;k ckgj [kqyh txg esa ;k fiNokM+s          space or backyard. The 'BaLA-Resources' can be

   ldrs gSaA mnkgj.k ds fy,] cjkens dh uhph nhokj ;k iQ+'kZ ij                furniture, stairs, pillars, ground, etc. For example,

   ldrs gSaA ckgj ck¡l ;k Vk;jksa ds [ksy] cky&fodkl dh lgt                   different types of writable surfaces. Tyre or bamboo

   vkSj okLrqdkjksa }kjk fd;k x;k gSA ckyk] vk¡xuokM+h ds ifjizs{;            their little fingers. All these have been identified,

                                                                        •	 Ensure after a day’s work:
                                                                           •		Is any water dripping / leaking from somewhere?
                                                                              If any pipe or taps has been left open? Close it
                                                                              promptly.
                                                                           •		Any electrical wire or switch is not left open?
                                                                              Close it promptly.
                                                                           •		A door or window that should be closed - is that
                                                                              left open? Close it promptly.
                                                                           •		Any chemical box has not been left open? Close it
                                                                              promptly.
                                                                           •		Any chemical box has not been left outside? Keep
                                                                              it inside promptly.
                                                                           •		Any sharp tool has not been left outside? Keep it
                                                                              inside promptly under lock.
                                                                           •		Any hole in the wall / floor or a pit / ditch / well
                                                                              is not open causing security hazard, in which an
                                                                              animal, child or an adult may accidentally get
                                                                              stuck or fall? Provide a secure cover on the top
                                                                              and secure fence around it and only then leave
                                                                              the premises.

	 budk mi;ksx tgk¡ Hkh                                                     	    Whenever any pigment, paint or colour is used any
  djsa] blds fuekZrk ls ;g                                                     where, it must be ensured from the manufacturer
                                                                               that it is free from toxic chemicals. For years,
  lqfuf'pr djsa fd blesa                                                       their manufacturers have been adding a range of
  fo"kSys jlk;u rks ugha                                                       chemicals that were toxic. Just their vapour or touch
  gSaA vusd o"kks± ls buds                                                     can let the toxins get inside our body. This will be
  fuekZrk jaxksa ij rjg&rjg                                                    harmful to children. These must not be used in the
  ds jlk;u Mkyrs jgs gSa                                                       work. Good manufacturers should be able to give

•	   x<+us @ lk¡ps okys vkSt+kjksa dks igys ls rS;kj j[ksa                 •	 Types of Cement
     x<+us okys en tSls fy[kkbZ dh rS;kjh esa x<+h vkd`fr]                 	 There are two types of cements - OPC (Ordinary
     vkd`fr&dfork] ckyk iV~V] ekid&Ldsy bR;kfn esa ;fn fdlh                   Portland Cement and PPC (Portland Pozzolana
                                                                              Cement). OPC becomes hard after use, but its shade
     vkStkj] lk¡ps vkfn dk mi;ksx gksuk gS] rks mls igys ls gh rS;kj          remains consistent. PPC has added fly ash, whose
     djuk gksxkA D;ksafd bUgsa iyLrj ;k iQ+'kZ dh Åijh lrg ds xhys            proportion is not consistent. Hence for any structural
     gksus dh voLFkk esa gh rqjUr mi;ksx esa ykuk gksrk gS] rHkh lgh <ax      work, repair of cracks, etc. PPC is fine. But for BaLA
     ls en cu ldsxkA ;gk¡ nsjh djus ls dk;Z fcxM+ Hkh ldrk gSA                work, in which cement pigment is added - to get
                                                                              a consistent shade, use only OPC cement in the

•	lhesUV ds izdkj                                                             possible to get the correct and consistent shade.

  fodYiksa dh vis{kk vf/d gks ldrh gS] fdUrq mudh vk;q yEch                  use it. In many remote sites, where such paints
  vkSj ns[k&js[k esa O;; de gksA tSls ckyk dh lHkh fy[kkbZ dh lrgksa         are not readily available, there may be a time lag
  dk mnkgj.k ysaA bUgsa cukus dk ljy] de ykxr dk fodYi bUgsa                 in its procurement. Hence, it will be useful to
                                                                             make such options in those situations. In making
  nhokj ij jaxus dk gSA ogha] tgk¡ dgha laHko gks] fy[kus dh LFkkbZ
                                                                             specifications of many BaLA resources for floor
  lrg cuk ldrs gSa] ftlesa lrg ij mQij fd;s tkus okys jax ds                 and wall, this has been kept in mind.
  vykok] ogh jax vUnj lrg ds fuekZ.k esa yxs lhesUV @ pwus ds
  elkys esa Hkh gksxkA blls Hkfo"; esa tc mQij dk jax mrj Hkh tk,xk

njkjksa dh laf{kIr tkudkjh                                                    Brief Introduction on Cracks
njkjsa Hkou ds fdlh fgLls esa vk jgh detksjh ds y{k.k gSaA le; ij             Crack shows symptom of weakness in a part of the
funku djus ls Hkou dh vk;q vkSj {kerk nksuksa gh c<+ tkrs gSaA gekjs          building. ‘A stitch in time saves nine’. If a crack is repaired
                                                                              in time, it increases the life span as well as efficiency and
Hkou esa dbZ rjg dh njkjsa gks ldrh gSa& iQ+'kZ ij] nhokj ij] Nr ij           performance of a building. A building may have different
;k muds tksM+ksa ijA gkykafd lHkh njkjsa gkfudkjd ugha gksrhaA ysfdu          types of cracks – on the floor, on the walls or the roof or
;g lqfuf'pr djus ds fy, fdlh izekf.kr lajpuk vfHk;Urk dks njkj                at their joints. However all cracks are not dangerous. But
t+:j fn[kk,¡ vkSj rHkh funku r; djsaA ;gk¡ crk, x, lHkh lq>ko ;ksX;           to identify the correct nature and cause of the crack, it
lajpuk vfHk;Urk }kjk lqfuf'pr djok ds gh mi;ksx esa yk,¡A iQ+'kZ              must be inspected by a qualified structural engineer to
                                                                              finalize the remedy. All suggestions given here should be
vkSj nhokj dh dqN izdkj dh njkjksa dh ejEer dks ckyk&txg ;k                   used only after recommendations by a qualified structural
ckyk&lalk/u ds fodkl ds lkFk Hkh tksM+k tk ldrk gSA                           engineer. While repairing some cracks of floor and wall,
                                                                              these can also be integrated with development of BaLA-
njkjksa ds dqN izdkj                                                          Settings and BaLA-Resources.
IkQ+'kZ esa njkj
    •	 iQ+'kZ dh lrg ij NksVh njkjsa                                          Different types of Cracks

nhokj esa njkjsa                                                                 •	 Deep cracks on the floor
   •	 nhokj ds IyLrj esa NksVh lrgh njkjsa (uhps nh xbZ fLFkfr;ksa ds
      vykok)                                                                  Wall Cracks

   •	 nhokj esa f[kM+dh @ njoktksa ds fyaVy ds Åij frjNh xgjh njkj

   •	 nhokj esa ,dne [kM+h xgjh njkj                                           •	Deep inclined crack in wall over the lintel of

   •	 nhokj ij dksbZ vU; njkj                                                  •	 Deep vertical crack in wall

  •	 Nr dh Åijh (ckgjh) lrg ij NksVh njkj
                                                                              Roof Cracks
;g lkekU; rkSj ij fn[kus okyh njkjsa gSa tks orZeku Hkouksa esa fn[krh gSaA     •	 Crack in (interior) roof soffit surface

Possible Causes for Dampness and its Remedies
Note : For any type of dampness present in the building that does not match those given in this table, then consult a
qualified structural engineer.
Nature of                 Possible Cause                                  Suggested Remedy
Dampness
1. Dampness on roof       •	 Water is stagnated on the roof since the •	 Clear the rain-water drain-out point of any clogging and
   under-side (side         slope / drain-out is insufficient / closed.     repair, if needed.
   that is visible from                                                   •	 Make a rain water drain-out point. Ensure that there is one
   inside of room)                                                          outlet of diameter 100-150mm (4”-6”) for every 35 square
                                                                            meter of roof area.
2. Water dripping         •	 The water-proofing layer is either non-      •	 Repair the joint of rain water outlet for any leakage.
   from the roof             existent or weakened.                        •	 Repair the water-proofing layer on the roof, if it is weakened.
                          •	 The roofing tiles have moved / are             Use appropriate water-proofing method, as per roof design.
                             broken.                                      •	 If the slope of the roof is insufficient, then correct it. It should
                                                                            not be less than 1:200 (for every 1 cm (1/2") rise, the sloped
                                                                            length should be at least 200 cm (8”).
                          •	 The roofing sheet has decayed /         •	 Replace the damaged roofing tiles / sheets, as per need.
                            broken / has holes in it / rubber washer •	 Tightly put new rubber / neoprene washers with bolts.
                            securing bolts are damaged.
                          •	 The roof has sunken due to weakening •	 Support the entire roof adequately with alternative support
                            / damage in the supporting under-               to take entire load. Open / repair the weakened / damaged
                            structure. Identify the solution with           under-structure. The work to be done under strict supervision
                            advice from a qualified structural              and guidance of qualified structural engineer.
                            engineer only.
                          •	 An electrical wire conduit / joint is        •	 After locating the opening in the electrical conduit, close it
                            open somewhere from where rain                  securely.
                            water is entering inside and spreading        •	 Waterproof the hole adequately.
                            in the roof.
                          •	 The water drain outlet joint is leaking.     •	 Correct the slope of the roof and lay new water-proofing.
                                                                          •	 On the periphery of the roof, make a new fillet (gola) along
                                                                    the roof-parapet wall joint.

                        thermal expansion-contraction
                        in heat-cold as a result of different
                        materials used for walling and roofing).
                        Dampness is entering from here.

   upper portion of       •	 There is crack in the parapet wall due         causes a crack in the parapet and water percolates inside.

                                            level is higher than the damp proof                   chemical treatment and physical method are
                                            course (DPC) of the foundation.                       possible.
                                                                                                  Chemical treatment is more practical and less
                                                                                                  expensive and least time consuming, but the
                                                                                                  skill to inject chemical and treat may not be
                                                                                                  available every where. (For this, commercially
                                                                                                  available chemical is pressure injected into the
                                                                                                  DPC area. The chemical spreads and forms a
                                                                                                  damp-proof layer and dries up.)
                                                                                                  Physical method is difficult and can only be
                                                                                                  done under direct supervision of a qualified
                                                                                                  structural engineer. (For this, the roof is
                                                                                                  adequately supported and at the DPC level,
                                                                                                  small portions of masonry are removed and
                                                                                                  a new DPC is casted in parts and removed
                                                                                                  masonry is put in place simultaneously. Entire
                                                                                                  building is not treated in one go, but in parts.) *

                                                                         If a flat roof is just over the wall or is inadequately

fudyh gks rks cjlkr dk ikuh Nr ls nhokj ij gh cgsxkA blls nhokj          wall. This may result in dampness inside. Roof and
ls Hkh ueh vUnj vk ldrh gSA cjlkr ds yEcs ekSle esa Nr vkSj nhokj        wall may have stains of fungus if there is prolonged
dkbZ vkSj dkfy[k ls dkys fu'kkuksa okyh Hkh gks ldrh gSA Nr ij eq¡Ms+j   rainy season. Parapet stops the rain water from falling

                                                                         to above mentioned problems. Fillet prevents water to

       Child-Friendly Urinal




cky&lqyHk ew=kky; D;ksa\                                                  Why Child-Friendly Urinal?
cpiu esa iM+h vknrsa] cM+s gksus rd lkFk nsrh gSaA vius 'kjhj vkSj        Habits formed in childhood remain there till adulthood.
                                                                          To keep oneself and the surroundings clean, to feel
vklikl ds okrkoj.k dks lkiQ&lqFkjk j[kuk] viuh ft+Eesnkjh                 responsible, to be independent or to develop sense of
le>uk] vkRefuHkZj gksuk] lkekftd ft+Eesnkjh le>us ds cht] cpiu            social responsibilities - the seeds of all these can be
ls gh fodflr gks ldrs gSaA cPpksa dh le> vkSj n`f"V ds vuq:i              inculcated only in the childhood. A urinal made according
cuk ew=kky; vkSj mldk lgh mi;ksx vkSj j[k&j[kko bu vknrksa dks            to children’s understanding, view and tendencies will
fodflr djsxkA dsoy ew=kky; cuk nsuk dkiQh ugha gS] cfYd ;g Hkh            facilitate correct usage and upkeep and will help in
                                                                          forming such hygienic habits. It is not just important to
t+:jh gS fd igys cM+s vkSj fiQj NksVs cPps mldk egRo le>sa vkSj           provide urinal, but also to first make the elders and then
fcuk Mj ds mldk mi;ksx djsaA vk¡xuokM+h esa 'kkSpky; dh vis{kk]           young children understand its importance and train them
cPps ew=kky; dk T;knk mi;ksx djrs gSaA                                    to effectively use it without fear. In Aanganwadis, children
                                                                          often use the urinals more than toilets.

       Friendly Toilet for Women, Adolescent Girls and Children




'kkSpky; D;ksa\                                                      Why Toilet?
ge tkurs gSa fd cpiu esa iM+h vknrsa] cM+s gksus rd lkFk nsrh gSaA   We know that habits formed in childhood remain with
                                                                     us till adulthood. To keep oneself and the surroundings
vius 'kjhj vkSj vklikl ds okrkoj.k dks lkkQ&lqFkjk j[kuk] viuh       clean, to feel re-sponsible, to be independent or to
ft+Eesnkjh le>uk] vkRefuHkZj gksuk] lkekftd ft+Eesnkjh le>us ds      develop sense of social responsibilities - the seeds
cht] cpiu ls gh fodflr gks ldrs gSaA cPpksa dh le> vkSj n`f"V        of all these can be inculcated only in the childhood
ds vuq:i cuk 'kkSpky; vkSj mldk lgh mi;ksx vkSj j[k&j[kko bu         and not later. A toilet made according to children’s
vknrksa dks fodflr djsxkA                                            understanding, view and tendencies will facilitate
                                                                     correct usage and up-keep and will help in forming such
                                                                     hygienic habits.
dsoy 'kkSpky; cuk nsuk dkiQh ugha gS] cfYd ;g Hkh t+:jh gS fd
NksVs cPps mldk egRo le>sa vkSj fcuk Mj ds mldk mi;ksx djsaA         It is not just important to provide toilet, but also to make
blds mi;ksx dks c<+kus ds fy, t+:jh gS fd ;g lHkh fgrxzkfg;ksa &     elders and young children understand its importance
NksVs cPpksa ] fd'kksjh ckfydkvksa] o;Ld vkSj xHkZorh efgykvksa dh   and train them to effectively use it without fear. To
                                                                     maximise its use, it should be according to needs of all
t+:jrksa ds vuqlkj cuk gksA                                          the beneficiaries - young children, adolescent girls, adult
                                                                     and pregnant women.
vk¡xuokM+h esa 'kkSpky; dh vis{kk] cPps vkSj efgyk,¡ ew=kky; dk
T;knk mi;ksx djrs gSaA                                               In Aanganwadis, children and women often use the
                                                                     urinals more than toilets.

Adaptation as per Need




                      119
t+:jr ds vuqlkj vuqdwyu
Adaptation as per Need
vk¡xuokfM+;ksa dk okrkoj.k csgrj lqxe vkSj vkjkenk;d cukus ds             To make the environment of existing Aanganwadis
fy, mlds dqN fgLlksa dks] ogk¡ dh t+:jr ds vuqdwy cukus dh                better, more comfortable and functional, as per need it
                                                                          may need adaptation.
vko';drk gks ldrh gSA
                                                                          For better natural light, ventilation, the ventilators,
csgrj izkd`frd gok vkSj jks'kuh ls lapkj ds fy, jks'kunku] f[kM+dh        windows and door may need adaptation. In hot climatic
vkSj njoktksa dks vuqdwy cuk;k tkuk pkfg,A xeZ izns'kksa esa Nr ls xehZ   regions, the roof must insulate the heat to reduce
vUnj de vk,] blfy, Nr rki&jks/d gksA vUnj ckgj lHkh txg                   its effect inside. All indoor and outdoor spaces may
                                                                          be conveniently accessible and also in direct visual
lqxerk ls vk&tk ldsa vkSj lHkh txg lh/h utj esa Hkh jgsa] blfy,           command. For this, the door and window may need
f[kM+dh&njokts esa iQsj cny ;k txgsa&cnyh dj ldrs gSaA ckgj n`';          relocation or interchange. To see the outside view or to
ns[kus vkSj iQ+'kZ ij fcuk txg ?ksjs cSBus ds fy, f[kM+dh esa gh cnyko    make a seat, without occupying floor space, a window
fd;k tk ldrk gSA                                                          may need modification.

                                                                          Wherever, there may be a need for screening or securing
tgk¡ dgha vkM+ ;k ifjlj dks lqjf{kr cukus dh t+:jr gS] ogk¡               the premises, as per situation, appropriate screen or safe
ifjfLFkfr ds vuqlkj vuqdwy vkM+ ;k lqjf{kr ukyh cukbZ tk ldrh gSA         guard grill can be made. It is important that all door,
lHkh f[kM+dh&njokts] vyekjh t+:jr iM+us ij cPps Hkh lqjf{kr rjhds         windows and almirah shutters have hardware that are
ls [kksy&cUn dj ldsa blfy, buesa yxh dq.Mh&gRFkk cky&lqyHk gks            child-friendly so that these can be easily operated to
;g vko';d gSA                                                             open or close by the children, when needed.

                                                                          Where there is need to take weight of the children, or
tgk¡ dgha Hkkj ysus dh t+:jr gks] rks Nr ls Vaxk Hkkj okgd rjktw          hang swings inside, (if there is no open space outside),
Vk¡xus ds fy, ;k (ckgj txg u gksus ij) d{k ds vUnj gh >wys yxkus          providing a secure hook on the roof / elsewhere will be
ds fy, dM+h dk izko/ku nsuk t+:jh gksxkA                                  essential.

                                                                          This section details out such general adaptations.
bl Hkkx esa vuqdwyu ds ,sls gh dqN lkekU; rjhdksa dk foLrkj gSA
                                                                          From the perspective of saving cost and time, these must

;s lHkh fodYi vkerkSj ij Hkou dh lajpukRed lqj{kk ls dksbZ                All the options generally do not compromise on

le>kSrk ugha djrs gSa] fiQj Hkh dk;Z ;kstuk cukrs le; fdlh ;ksX;          desirable to consult a qualified Architect or Engineer at
okLrqdkj ;k vfHk;Urk ls lykg djuk vPNk jgsxkA                             the time of planning this work.

izkd`frd jks'kuh vkSj gok ds eqn~ns dks le>uk                               Understanding the Issue of
                                                                            Natural Light and Ventilation
izkd`frd jks'kuh vkSj gok lHkh ds thou vkSj fodkl ds fy,                    Natural light and ventilation are essential for sustenance
vko';d gSA i;kZoj.k vkSj cky fodkl esa budk [kkl egÙo gSA dbZ               of life of all. These are important from the perspective
                                                                            of environment and development. Many Aanganwadis
vk¡xuokfM+;ksa esa i;kZIr izkd`frd jks'kuh vkSj okrk;u ugha gksrk gS]       do not have sufficient natural light and ventilation, as a
ftlds dkj.k vUnj dh xfrfof/;ksa dks vPNs ls djus dk ekgkSy gh               result of which, the activities in the interiors do not have
ugha cu ikrk gSA ,slk] t+:jr ls de f[kM+dh] njokts] jks'kunku ds            a conducive environment. This may happen due to less
izko/ku dh otg ls Hkh gks ldrk gSA budk lgh fn'kk esa u gksuk ;k            than adequate provision of window, ventilators or door.
cUn iM+s jguk Hkh ,d dkj.k gks ldrk gSA dbZ ckj f[kM+dh] njokts             Their improper orientation or being closed can also be
                                                                            a reason. Many times the window, ventilator or door
vkSj jks'kunku i;kZIr Hkh gksaxs vkSj lgh fn'kk esa Hkh] ij muds Bhd vkxs   may be adequate in number and orientation, but may
fdlh nwljs Hkou ;k pkjnhokjh dh vkM+ vk tkrh gSA blds dkj.k Hkh             have an obstruction right in front of them in the form of
i;kZIr jks'kuh vkSj okrk;u #d tkrk gSA                                      another building or a boundary wall that impedes the
                                                                            flow of natural light and ventilation.
;gk¡ xfrfof/ d{k esa izkd`frd jks'kuh vkSj okrk;u c<+kus ds dqN ljy
                                                                            Here, some simple solutions to improve natural light and
mik; fn, x, gSa] ftlls d{k ds vUnj vkjkenk;d vkSj vuqdwy                    ventilation are given that will make the activity room
ifjfLFkfr cukbZ tk ldrh gSA                                                 comfortable and facilitative for the activities.

•	   lcls igys ;g lqfuf'pr djsa fd] D;k ckgj [kqyus okys f[kM+dh]           •	 First, ensure if the combined area of all the openings
     njokts vkSj jks'kunku dk dqy lfEefyr {ks=kiQy] dejs ds iQ+'kZ             opening outside — door, window and ventilators is
     ds {ks=kiQy dk 15» ls 20» gS ;k ugha\ ;fn blls de gS] rks                 between 15-20% of the area of the floor of the room.
                                                                               If it is less, then new window/ door / ventilator should
     ifjfLFkfr ds vuqlkj u, f[kM+dh @ njokts @ jks'kunku dk izko/ku            be made — keeping in mind, the human or natural
     cuk,¡ tks LFkkuh;] ekuoh; ;k izkd`frd vkink tSls vkx] Hkwd¡i]             hazard safety considerations of fire, earthquake,
     rwiQku] HkwL[kyu] ck<+] lqukeh vkfn ds {ks=k esa vkus dh lEHkkouk         cyclone, land slide, flood, tsunami, etc. — as ap-
     dks è;ku esa j[k dj cuk gksA ;fn {ks=kiQy i;kZIr gS (;kus dejs ds         plicable in the region. If the area is sufficient (i.e.
     iQ+'kZ ds {ks=kiQy ds 15% ls 20% ds cjkcj ;k T;knk gS) ysfdu              equal or greater than 15% to 20% of floor area of

                                                                               Some more simple options follow. Based on the

                                                                            1.	 Height of the finished sill should be comfortably

       Reducing Heat from the Roof




Nr ls rki de D;ksa\                                                     Why Reduce Heat from the Roof?
                                                                        Of the total heat getting inside from the sun light, upto
/wi ls vkus okyh dqy xehZ dh djhc 60» dks vUnj ykus ds fy, Nr
                                                                        60% can enter from the roof. In other words, if the heat
ft+Eesnkj gks ldrh gSA nwljs 'kCnksa esa] ;fn Nr ls vkus okyh xehZ de   coming in from the roof is reduced, the rooms can be
dh tk, rks dejs vUnj ls vkjkenk;d cuk, tk ldrs gSaA ;g ckr              made conformable - in regions that are hot and warm. The
lHkh xeZ bykdksa ds fy, ekU; gksxhA Nr ls vUnj vkus okyh xehZ dks       most basic methods of reducing heat from the roof are:
de djus dk lcls cqfu;knh rjhds gSa%
                                                                        1. Making roof reflective for sun light
1- Nr dks /wi ds fy, ijkorhZ cukuk                                      2. 'Shade' the roof
2- Nr ij ’Nk;k’ djuk                                                    3. Making the roof thermally insulative
3- Nr dks rki&jks/d cukuk
                                                                        There can be various ways to put these methods into
bu lHkh rjhdksa dks O;ogkj esa ykus ds vusd fodYi gks ldrs gSaA ;gk¡    practice. Here one example for each option is given - such
gj rjhds dk ,d&,d mnkgj.k fn;k x;k gS ftls cukus] yxkus vkSj            that the process of making, fixing and using does not
                                                                        consume any electricity. There can be more such ways,
mi;ksx djus esa fctyh dk O;; u gksA ;gk¡ fn;s rjhdksa ds vykok Hkh
                                                                        other than those given here.
vU; rjhds gks ldrs gSaA

Nr ls rki de djus dh ekud dk;Z&{kerk                                    Performance Standard for
                                                                        Reducing Heat from the Roof
vko';d
•	 xehZ ds ekSle esa] nksigj esa] dejs ds vUnj dk rkieku ckgj           Essential
   ds rkieku ls de ls de 5&70 lsfYl;l rd de jgs vkSj                    •	 The temperature inside, during summer afternoon
                                                                           should be at least 5-7°C less than outside.
   vkjkenk;d jgsA
                                                                        •	 Electricity or mechanical means should not be used to
•	 dejs dk rkieku vkjkenk;d cukus esa fdlh fctyh ;k e'khu ds

Methods and Ways to Reduce Heat from the Roof
fodYi&1 Nr dks /wi ds fy, ijkorhZ cukuk                                       Option-1 Making Roof Reflective for Sun-light
•	 Nr ij /wi iM+us okyh lrg dks liQsn jaxuk                                   •	 Painting the surface receiving sunlight in white
	 Nr ij iM+us okyh /wi dk vf/dk¡'k fgLlk okil okrkoj.k esa Nr                    colour
                                                                                 Most of the sunlight and heat falling on the roof surface
   dh ckgjh lrg dks liQsn jax esa jaxus ls Hkstk tk ldrk gSA blds fy,            can be reflected back into the environment by painting
   igys ;g lqfuf'pr dj ysa fd Nr dh tyjks/u {kerk i;kZIr gS ;k                   this surface white. First, ensure that the roof has proper
   ughaA ;fn ugha gS] rks bls cuk,¡A                                                           water-proofing. If not, then undertake it.
   (ns[ksa i`"B 137) ty jks/u Bhd                                                              (See page 137). Only after doing proper
                                                                                               water-proofing, proceed further. Painting
   djus ds ckn vkxs c<+A   as Nr dh                                                            the surface that directly receives sunlight
   ftl lrg ij lh/h /wi iM+rh gS]                                                               with white paint reflects a major part of
   mls liQsn jax esa jaxus ls ml ij                                                            the light as well as the heat back into the
   iM+us okyh /wi dk ,d cM+k fgLlk]                                                            environment and the heat is not able to
                                                                                               enter inside the building. Painting two
   viuh xehZ ds lkFk okrkoj.k esa
                                                                                               coats of lime wash on roof surface is the
   okil ykSV tkrk gS vkSj dejs ds                                                              most inexpensive environment friendly
   vUnj xehZ ugha vk ikrh gSA Nr ij                                                            option. This can be repeated after cleaning
   jaxus dk lcls lLrk vkSj i;kZoj.k                                                            the roof every year, just before the onset
                                                                                 of summers. Other options include water-proof white
   ds çfr ft+Eesnkj fodYi pwus dh nks ijrksa esa liQsnh gSA ;g gj o"kZ xehZ
                                                                                 cement paint or acrylic based exterior grade paint. If
   esa ekSle ds igys] Nr lkiQ djds djuh gksxhA vU; fodYiksa esa ikuh             the roof space is likely to be used for walking or for
   ls lqjf{kr liQsn lhesUV dk jax ;k ,Øfyd vk/kfjr liQsn jax gks                 some activity, then the roof can be water-proofed using
   ldrs gSA  a ;fn Nr ij pyus&fiQjus ;k mi;ksx djus dh txg gks rks jax           white cement or lime which can then double up as
   dh ctk, liQsn lhesUV ;k pwus dk gh tyjks/u fd;k tk ldrk gS tks                water-proofing as well as heat insulation layer. These
                                                                                 are ways that have been used successfully in traditional
   tyjks/u ds lkFk gh rki&jks/u Hkh djsxkA ;g lc ikjEifjd Hkouksa                buildings for centuries. These can also be taken up at
   esa lfn;ksa ls fd;k tkrk jgk gSA ;g dk;Z LFkkuh; Lrj ij gh fd;k tk            local level.

Shapes engraved on plain writable surface. These
should also be painted in colours that are in contrast to
the colour of board surface. The board and the engraved
shapes must be within the reach of children’s hand.

Please Note
Ensure that the colour of all forms, shapes, letters, numerals is in contrast to the colour of the background board. Also the colour of the surface
should be either dark green / blue or black in matt finish and without any gloss. All letters and numbers must be made in simple and clear font.

lkekftd vkSj jpukRed fodkl dh Hkh txg gS] tgk¡ os nwljksa ls                          Creative and social development takes place. Here,
lh[kuk] ck¡Vuk] enn djuk] tSls laLdkj Hkh lh[krs gSaA cPps] ;gk¡                      children learn values like sharing, helping others or
fcuk o;Ldksa (dk;ZdrkZvksa @ lgkf;dkvksa) dh enn ds Hkh] Lo;a                         learning from others. Children can also do their activities

dqN cqfu;knh ckrsa                                                      Some Basic Points
                                                                        1.	 In the entire tyre play-ground, lay a layer of well-
1-	 bl [ksy txg esa 450 fe-eh- (1*&6**) xgjh vkSj vPNs ls                   seized fine sand 450mm deep to act like a soft
    Nuh gqbZ eghu jsr fcNh gks] rks ;g mRre jgsxh vkSj cPpksa ds            cushion. So that children are not hurt while playing
    [ksyrs&fxjrs&iM+rs le; uje xn~ns dk dke djsxhA                          tipping or falling.
2-	 Vk;j jsfM;y u gksaA buesa vUnj LVhy dh iRrh ;k tkyh gksrh gS        2.	 Do not use radial tyres, since they are steel belted /
    tks cPpkas dk yx ldrh gSA                                               lined, which can hurt the children.
                                                                        3.	 Make holes in the bottom most surfaces of tyres used
3-	 vyx&vyx [ksy&midj.kksa esa yxs Vk;jksa dh lcls fupyh lrg                in different play equipments, such that water is not
    esa bl izdkj Nsn dj nsa fd cjlkr dk ikuh muesa bdB~Bk u gks             collected during rains (Mosquitoes may breed in
    lds (ikuh bdB~Bk gksus ls ePNj iSnk gks ldrs gSa)A                      collected water).
4-	 lHkh uksd @ /kj @ dksus vPNh rjg f?kl ds xksy dj nsa] ftlls         4.	 Grind or sand all sharp edges, corners and round
    cPpksa dks [ksyrs le; u yx ldsA                                         them, so that children are not hurt.
                                                                        5.	 Wherever bamboo is available, it can be used to
5-	 tgk¡ ck¡l miyC/ gks ogk¡ [kEcksa] cYyh] bR;kfn ds fy, ck¡l dk           make support or frame.
    mi;ksx dj ldrs gSaA                                                 6.	 All colours and paints used must be non-toxic.
6-	 mi;ksx esa fy, x;s lHkh jax vkSj isUV vfo"kSys gksaA                7.	 The sand may become harder over period of time
7-	 l[r gks jgh fcNh jsr dks le;&le; ij <hyk djus dh                        and may need loosening from time to time.
    vko';drk jgsxhA                                                     8.	 Different tyres can be collected and donated by the

c.	 Earth Mounds for Roli-Poli

                                                                     mi;ksx
                                                                     NksVs&cPpksa dks bl mez esa yq<+dus&iq<+dus esa cgqr vkuUn vkrk gSA ;g
                                                                     xfrfof/ muds lEiw.kZ 'kkjhfjd fodkl esa egÙoiw.kZ gSA blds ekè;e
                                                                     ls muds 'kjhj dh LFkwy vkSj lw{e isf'k;ksa dk fodkl vkSj leUo;
                                                                     rS;kj gksrk gSA

                                                                     Usage
                                                                     At the young age, children have great fun in rolling
                                                                     over (Roli-Poli). This activity is also good for their entire
                                                                     physical development. This develops their gross and
                                                                     fine motor muscles as well as their coordination.




bls dgk¡ cuk,¡\                                                      Where to Make ?
blh <ky dh rjkbZ ij [kqyh txg gks ftlls yq<+dus&iq<+dus ds ckn       Its base must have sufficient clear area, so that after
                                                                     rolling over, children do not collide with another play
cPps fdlh nwljh xfrfof/ ;k [ksy midj.k ls cPps Vdjk u tk,¡A          equipment or an activity. This space must be made
;g txg [kqys esa] [ksy dh txg & tSls ifg;k ;k ck¡l&cYyh [ksy         with or along Tyre play or Play Settings using Bamboo
txg & ds lkFk gh cuh gksA bls eqDrk¡xu esa cSBus dh txg dh rjg Hkh   / Timber. This can also be developed as seating for
cuk;k tk ldrk gSA (ns[ksa i`"B la[;k 252)                            Amphitheatre. (See page no 252)

D;k vkSj dSls cuk,¡\                                                 What and how to Make?
blds fy,] miyC/ txg ds vuqlkj 900&1200 fe-eh- (3’ ls 4’)             Based on available space, make an earth mound about
                                                                     900-1200mm (3’ to 4’) high, whose slope should be
mQ¡pk Vhyk ftlesa <ky eè;e gks & rhoz u gks & cuk,¡A ;g uhps eycs    moderate – and not steep. Below the top 450mm (1’-6”)
vkSj mQijh 450 fe-eh- (1’&6”) feV~Vh dh eksVh ijr ls cuk;k tk        layer of earth, there can be infill of debris from repair
ldrk gSA bl ij nslh ?kkl Hkh mxk ldrs gSa] tks <ky dh feV~Vh dks     work also. On the top surface, local species of soft grass
idM+s jgsxhA Vhys dh vkd`fr yEch] xksy ;k ?kweh gqbZ & LFky dh       can also be planted, to hold the earth on the slope.
ifjfLFkfr ds vuqlkj dSlh Hkh gks ldrh gSA blesa mQij pksVh ij iBkj   The shape of the mound can be elongated, rounded or
                                                                     turned – whatever is conducive on the site. On the ridge,
gks] uksd u gksA                                                     there should be platue – it should not be sharp edge.

d.	 Space to Play with Mud, Sand and Water




feV~Vh] jsr vkSj ikuh ls [ksyus dh txg dk egRo                       Importance of Space to Play with Mud,
cPpksa dks dqN Nwuk] fdlh pht dks vkdkj nsuk vkSj fofHkUu            Sand and Water
izkd`frd lkefxz;ksa dks vyx&vyx <ax ls rksM+uk] ejksM+uk] fxjkuk]    It is only natural for children to touch, give shape to

Please note
1.	 All ends of MS pipe / bamboo should be rounded for child-friendliness.
2.	 All corners and edges of low height wall /screen along the ramp should be rounded for child- friendliness.
3.	 Small children have a tendency to touch and put things in the mouth. With age and appropriate guidance,
    this does change. Keeping in mind these tendencies, it is important to make Aanganwadiis safe and child-
    friendly. Ensure that paints used on pipe are non-toxic.
4.	 Slope can also be made in mud or stone. Although ensure that top surface is good to take rain and the
    abrasion of walking.
5.	 Ensure that no poisonous chemical is present in portions of bamboo that are likely to come in contact with
    children.

ldrk gS] ftlls uhao esa cjlkrh ikuh ughsa tk ldsxk vkSj Hkou ds         When made along the wall of building, this also acts like a

pkjksa vksj tehu esa ueh dk leku Lrj cuk;s j[krk gSA blls] okrkoj.k     into the foundation and retains uniform moisture level in
esa lnhZ&xehZ ds rkieku ;k ueh ds vUrj ls] iQSyus lqdM+us okyh          the soil all around the building. This prevents any cracking

vkrh gSa vkSj u gh og /¡lrk gSA tc isM+ ds bnZ&fxnZ gks] rc tM+ksa ds   variation in summer or winter in buildings made on sites

	    This strong wall will be sufficient to withstand the load of infill mud in the stage. Use the locally available loose
     soil and stone to infill the stage. Tamp and consolidate this infill. Infill shall be upto 450mm (1’-6”). There can be
     some cracks appearing on the mortar laid on the bamboo wall. Fill these with fresh mud paste. If the top edge of
     the bamboo wall is broken, repair or mend it. Now the stage is almost ready.

                                                                        XIII.	tSls      eap ds fy,] oSls gh eqDrk¡xu dh uhao dh fu'kkunsgh djds

                                                                    Just like stage, mark the layout of the amphitheatre and
                                                                    dig the foundation. The bamboo walls of amphitheatre
                                                                    will be of different heights as per the levels needed in
                                                                    the design of amphitheatre. If any roof is to be tied over
                                                                    the amphitheatre then the vertical bamboo’s in the wall
can extent up by 250mm (10”) above the top most finished level to provide support. For amphitheatre, using the method
given for stage, first erect the outermost wall for the highest level. Then prepare the foundation for the next wall.

	     Round finish the top most edge of the wall. Make the bamboo wall for the next level. In this intermediate wall, the
      bamboo strip mesh is needed only for the top portion (the portion that will be embedded inside the infill need not
      have the retaining mesh wall).




  f?kjs fgLls esa uhps cM+s iRFkj vkSj lw[kh feV~Vh dk Hkjko djsaA uhps ds [kkyh fgLls esa feV~Vh u ljd lds] blesa Hkkjh iRFkjksa gksuk Bhd jgsxkA
XVII.
 lHkh ryksa esa feV~Vh Hkjko ds ckn bldh dVkbZ djsaA feV~Vh dh NikbZ esa ;fn dqN njkjsa fn[ksa rks mUgsa HkjsaA mQijh xksykbZ ;fn dgha VwVh gks rks bls
 Hkh xksy djsaA
		
 In the enclosed area, infill large stone boulders on the bottom and loose mud on the top. In the bottom portion,
      putting heavy, large stones will be useful so that the infill mud may not move. Tamp and compact all the infill
      materials. If there are any cracks visible in the surface of any wall, fill them with mud mortar paste. Repair the top
      rounded portions of all walls, as per need.




                                                     XVIII.  mQijh lrg vPNs ls Hkjus ds ckn] ml ij ikuh fNM+dsaA blds mQij eap vkSj eqDrk¡xu ds
                                                            ryksa ij vPNs ls feV~Vh dh gh fyikbZ djsaA blds lw[kus ds ckn ;g mi;ksx ds fy, rS;kj gSA
                                                     	     On the top surface, after proper compaction, spray water. On this, using
                                                           mud mortar paste, properly lay an even coat. After drying, the Stage and
                                                           Amphitheatre are ready for use.

     ds ,d vkfnoklh leqnk; }kjk fd;k x;k gSA                                            fully developed and executed by a tribal community in

	Courtyard




vk¡xu gksus dk vFkZ                                                                Meaning of having a Courtyard
vk¡xuokM+h esa ;fn vk¡xu gh u gks rks dSlh vk¡xuokM+h\ Hkkjr ds                    The word ‘Aangan’ in Aanganwadi literally means the
                                                                                   courtyard. Hence, imagine, if there is an Aanganwadi
fdlh Hkh izkar esa] pkgs og dSls Hkh tyok;q {ks=k esa D;ksa u gks & lnhZ           without it, what kind of Aanganwadi would it be? In any
ds bykds] xehZ ds bykds] rVh; bykds & lHkh clkgVksa esa vk¡xu                      region of India, irrespective of its climate – whether it is a
fdlh u fdlh :i esa t:j gksrk gSA lnhZ ds bykds esa fnu esa dqN /wi                 cold region, warm region, coastal region – a courtyard is
lsadus ds fy,] rks xehZ ds bykds esa lqcg&'kke B.Mh gok ds vkuUn                   integral to the habitat form. In the cold region, it may be to
vkSj fnu esa xeZ gok ckgj [khapus ds fy,A mel Hkjs rVh; bykdksa esa                enjoy the warm sun in the day, in a hot region - to enjoy the
                                                                                   cool breeze in the mornings or late evenings and to pull
vk¡xu] Hkou ds vUnj vPNh gok dk lapkj djus esa enn djrk gSA                        out hot air from inside in the day. In the humid climate, it
vk¡xu gekjh laLd`fr dk vfHkUu fgLlk gS vkSj gekjs ?kjsyw ifjos'k                   helps in circulating wind inside the building. Courtyard is
dh ,d vko';d t:jrA vk¡xuokM+h vkus okys cPpksa dks ;fn vius                        an indispensable part of our culture and an essential need
?kjsyw ifjos'k ls ifjfpr ifjos'k vk¡xuokM+h ifjlj esa pkfg,] rks vk¡xu             of our residential habitat. If, for various reasons, children
mldk vfHkUu fgLlk gksxkA vk¡xu dqN v/chp dh txg gS & ckgj                          must have an Aanganwadi environment that is familiar
                                                                                   and extension to their own home, it must have a courtyard.
vkSj vUnj ds chpA ;g txg dqN ckgj dks vUnj dh vksj vkSj vUnj                       Courtyard is a setting situated somewhere in-between – the
dks ckgj dh vksj foLrkj Hkh nsrh gS vkSj lesV Hkh ysrh gSA blfy, tc                outside and inside. It expands the outside - little bit inside
ckgj txg de iM+ jgh gks rks og iQSy dj vk¡xu esa vk tkrh gS &                      and lets the inside to be spread out little bit, by enclosing
tc vUnj txg de iM+ jgh gks] rks og fNVd ds ckgj vk¡xu esa Hkh                      outside. So, if the space outside is limited, it expands into
                                                                                   the courtyard – or if the inside space is constrained, it steps




    vUnj          vk¡xu             ckgj                  vUnj             vk¡xu          ckgj            vUnj       vk¡xu        ckgj
    Indoor        Courtyard         Outdoor               Indoor           Courtyard Outdoor              Indoor     Courtyard    Outdoor

pyh tkrh gSA vk¡xu ds dqN fgLls esa Nk;k Hkh gks ldrh gS & tkiQjh                  out into the courtyard. Part of the courtyard can also be
;k epku lsA dqN csysa p<+kbZ tk ldrh gSa tks vk¡xu esa dqN Nk;k dj                 shaded – with a trellis. Some vines can climb on this trellis
                                                                                   to shade the courtyard. If it is hot inside, then one can work
nsaA tc vUnj xehZ gks rks yksx ckgj vk¡xu esa Nk;k esa dke dj ldrs gSaA            in the shade in the courtyard, outside. If the vines are winter
;fn csysa 'khr&dkyhu ir>jh gksa rks lnhZ esa tkiQjh vkSj epku ds uhps              deciduous, then in winters, there will be sunlight in the
Hkh /wi jgsxhA ;fn vk¡xu dk foU;kl ,slk gks fd tc fnu esa vk¡xuokM+h               courtyard below the trellis. If the building is planned such
pyrh gks rc ;g Nk;k esa jgs & rc tkiQjh & epku dh Hkh t:jr ugha                    that during Aanganwadi functioning hours, there is shade in
jgsxhA vk¡xu ca/s gq, dks [kksyrk gS vkSj [kqys gq, dks ck¡/rk gSA ;gh             the courtyard, then perhaps there may not be any need for a
                                                                                   trellis. Courtyard opens that which is bound and encloses that
mldh lqanjrk gSA                                                                   which is open. This is the beauty of a courtyard.

	     Waster Water Mini Garden




vk¡xuokM+h esa cxhpk                                                      Garden in an Aanganwadi
NksVs cPpksa ds lEiw.kZ fodkl ds fy, mudk isM+&ikS/ksa vkSj izd`fr ls     It is most important for children to come in close contact
                                                                          with the nature for their overall development. Often,
lEidZ gksuk cgqr egRroiw.kZ gSA vdlj vk¡xuokM+h esa ihus ds ikuh          there is scarcity of drinking water in the Aanganwadis,
dh gh eqf'dy gksrh] rks ,sls esa cxhps esa ikuh dSls vk,\ ,d NksVk lk     so how will the water for plants be arranged? A small
cxhpk] tks cgqr de ikuh ls cu lds] vk¡xuokM+h esa cuk;k tk ldrk           garden that can be irrigated with little water can be made
gSA dbZ vk¡xuokfM+;ksa esa uydwi (gS.MiEi) yxk gksrk gSA vdlj             in an Aanganwadi. Many Aanganwadis have a hand
bldk cgqr lk ikuh O;FkZ cg tkrk gSA ;g ikuh lkiQ Hkh gS vkSj O;FkZ        pump. Often a lot of water from this pump is wasted.
                                                                          The water is clean, but also wasted. Many times, some
HkhA dbZ ckj ikuh ihus dh txg ls FkksM+k cgqr ikuh O;FkZ cg gh tkrk       water from drinking water station is also wasted. In many
gSA vxj cjru ek¡tus dh txg gks rks vdlj mlesa ydM+h dks tyh               places, the utensils are cleaned with water and wood or
jk[k ls cjru eatrs gSaA ;gk¡ ls Hkh jk[k feyk ikuh cg dj tkrk gSA         coal ash - left after cooking the meals. From here also,
D;ksa u bl ikuh dks lgst dj cxhps dh D;kfj;ksa dh vksj eksM+ nsa &        wood-ash mixed water is drained out. Why not conserve
lk¡i Hkh ej tk, vkSj ykBh Hkh ugha VwVs! ,slk ikuh ftlesa fdlh rjg        and direct this water towards the garden? Water that
                                                                          does not contain any chemical or soap / detergent is safe
dk lkcqu ;k jlk;u ugha gks] cxhps ds ikS/ksa ds fy, mi;qDr gS] Hkys       for plants, even if its quantity is small.
gh mldh ek=kk de gh gksA
                                                                          What to grow in the Garden?
cxhps esa D;k mxk,sa\                                                     Water mixed with wood-ash is good to grow Banana,
jk[k /qys cjruksa dk ikuh] dsys] iihrs vkSj equxs (lgtu) dks mxkus        Papaya and Drumstick trees. The fruits of these trees
                                                                          provide good and healthy nutrition supplement to
ds fy, cgqr vPNk gSA bu rhuksa isM+ksa ds iQy cPpksa ds iks"k.k ds vPNs   children in Aanganwadis. The saplings of these trees
iwjd gSa vkSj LokLF;o/Zd gSaA bUgsa vklikl dh ou ;k ckxokuh okyh          can be brought from a nearby Forest Nursery or from the
ulZjh ;k ckxokuh foHkkx ls ckr djds vk¡xuokM+h esa mxk;k tk ldrk          Horticulture Department. If monkeys create menace in
gSA vxj vkl&ikl cUnjksa dk mRikr gks rks fiQj cxhps esa fofHkUu rjg       the area, then, the garden can have plants with different
ds iQwy] iÙh] jax] vkdkj] lqxU/] vkd`fr okys ikS/ks D;kfj;ksa esa yxk,¡   types of flowers, leaves, colours, shapes, fragrance,
                                                                          shapes, etc. This will not just enhance the aesthetic
tk ldrs gSa A buls u dsoy lkSUn;Z dk fodkl gksxk cfYd ;gk¡ dbZ            appreciation, but also help in planning creative and
rjg dh l`tukRed vkSj ekufld xfrfof/;k¡ Hkh dh tk ldrh gSaA                cognitive activities. Some medicinal plants can also be
blesa vkS"kf/&xq.k okys dqN ikS/s Hkh mxk,s tk ldrs gSaA                  grown in this garden.

Annexure - 3b Partnership / Convergence with Other Govt. Departments
Existing Aanganwadis may require basic amenities to function better. This can be done by converging or with help of
various departments. The list of common item for which this convergence can be done is given below:


 Items of basic amenities in existing Aanganwadis                                   Convergence Agency /
                                                                                    Partnership
 C.      Items of Basic Amenities
 1       Providing safe and potable / adequate drinking water                       PHED
 2       Providing and fixing Force and Lift Pump adapter                           PHED
 3       Providing water storage tank on terrace / lower level                      PHED / Nirmal Bharat Abhiyan (NBA)
 4       Providing separate drinking water point for Aanganwadi and School          PHED / NBA
         children.
 5       Providing hand wash point for children and adults (separate)               PHED / NBA
 6       Proving water connection in kitchen and utensil wash area                  PHED / NBA
 7       Providing baby friendly urinal                                             PHED / NBA
 8       Providing toilet for children and ladies                                   PHED / NBA
 9       Providing water connection for all the above                               PHED / NBA
 10      Providing disposal of waste water from urinal                              PHED / NBA
 11      Providing disposal of waste water from wash area                           PHED / NBA
 12      Providing disposal of waste water from drinking water area                 PHED / NBA
 13      Providing soak pit for urinal                                              PHED / NBA
 14      Providing plantation along with necessary excavation                       Horticulture / Social Forestry
                                                                                    Department
 15      Making Boundary wall / Fencing on existing boundary wall                   Local body (Panchayat/Municipality)

About Vinyãs and BaLA
foU;kl LFkkiR; vuqla/ku vkSj vkdYiu dk dsanz gS] ftldk è;s; gS fd                 Vinyãs is a centre for architectural research and design, whose
                                                                                  goal is to ‘Enrich Habitat for All, Responsibly, Innovatively,
vius fopkjksa vkSj dke ls ^lHkh ds fy,] gj dgha] ft+Eesnkj vkSj u, <¡x            Everywhere ‘ through its ideas and work. The idea of BaLA was
ls] lq?kj* cu ldsaA ckyk dk fopkj blh dM+h esa lcls igys izkFkfed                 developed as a continuation of this for primary and elementary
vkSj izkjfEHkd 'kkykvksa ds fy, rS;kj fd;k x;kA bldh 'kq#vkr 1997                 schools. Its conception started in 1997 in Lok Jumbish Project in
esa jktLFkku dh yksd tqfEc'k ifj;kstuk esa gqbZA bl ij xgu vuqla/ku               Rajasthan. In 2000-2001, a more comprehensive research and
vkSj fopkjksa dks flyflysokj <¡x ls :i nsus dk dk;Z ;wfulsIkQ ds lg;ksx           systematic development of ideas took place with the support from
                                                                                  UNICEF. This was an interdisciplinary work in which about 150
ls 2000&2001 esa gqvkA ;g vUrj&fo"k;h dk;Z Fkk ftlesa djhc 150                    people participated from diverse disciplines ranging from child
yksxksa us] tks cky fodkl] f'k{kk] ikB~;Øe fuekZ.k] Hkk"kk] xf.kr] foKku]         development, education, curriculum development, language,
okrkoj.k] l¡Ld`fr] okLrqdyk] vfHk;kfU=kdh] vkfn] fofo/ {ks=kksa ls FksA           mathematics, science, environment, culture, to architecture and
ckyk ds ewy esa ;g vo/kkj.kk gS fd pw¡fd cPps gj le; lh[krs gSa vkSj              engineering. Since children learn all the time and are always
ges'kk fdlh u fdlh HkkSfrd okrkoj.k esa jgrs gSa rks D;ksa u iwjs okrkoj.k        encompassed by a physical environment, why not develop the
                                                                                  entire environment as resource for their play, experience and
dks gh muds lh[kus] [ksyus] le>us ds l¡alk/u ds :i esa cjrk tk,A                  learning - this is at the core of BaLA. For example, the security
mnkgj.k ds fy,] f[kM+dh ds t¡xys & vdlj bUgsa o;Ld Hkou dh lqj{kk                 grills - often the adults put them as a security measure in the
ds fy, f[kM+dh&cjkenksa esa tM+ nsrs gSa vkSj ;gh cPpksa ds fy, tsy cu            windows or corridors, but from the child’s perspective this may
tkrk gSA D;k bu yksgs dh lyk[kksa dks cky fodkl dh n`f"V ls mi;ksxh               be a jail. Is it possible to modify these grills to become a toy or
dksbZ f[kykSuk cuk ldrs gSa] ftlls fd bldk ^tsy&iuk* gV tk, vkSj                  a learning aid from child's perspective such that its ‘jail-ness’
                                                                                  goes away? Or planting trees and plants that are conducive to
cPpksa dh utj ls lkspk okrkoj.k mUgsa ns ldsa\ ;k ckgj ,sls isM+&ikS/ksa          children’s behaviour and needs. Nearly 150 such ideas for BaLA
dks yxkuk tks cPpksa ds cky&lqyHk O;ogkj vkSj xfrfof/;ksa ds vuqdwy               Settings and Resources were developed. That school buildings
gksaA ,sls djhc 150 ckyk&txgksa vkSj lalk/uksa ds fopkj rS;kj fd, x,A             and the environment should be able to provide maximum
Hkou vkSj mldk okrkoj.k viuk vf/dre 'kS{kf.kd vkSj cky&fodkl                      educational and child development value to the children - this
dk ewY; cPpksa dks de&ls&de ykxr esa ns ldsa] bl lksp ds lkFk                     is thought behind BaLA. BaLA ideas have been developed such
                                                                                  that these can be integrated in the existing buildings during
ckyk dks rS;kj fd;k x;k gSA igys ls cus Hkouksa dh ejEer] cnyko ds                repair, adaptation or up-gradation, while also be incorporated
nkSjku ;k fIkQj u, cuus okys Hkouksa esa bldk lekos'k gks ldrk gSA bldk           in new to be designed buildings. The positive impact of this has
ldkjkRed vlj cPpksa ds ukek¡du] mifLFkfr] [kkyh le; ds lnqi;ksx]                  been observed in children’s enrolment, attendance, use of ‘free’
miyC/ txg dk lnqi;ksx vkSj cPpksa dh lh[kus&le>us dh izfØ;k ij                    unstructured time, effective use of available space as well as in
dbZ txg ns[kk x;kA 2005 ls vc rd foU;kl us bls loZ f'k{kk vfHk;ku                 the learning process of children in many places. Since 2005,
                                                                                  with Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (Universalisation of Elementary
esa dsanz vkSj jkT; ljdkjksa ds lkFk] ;wfulsIkQ vkSj fo'o cSad] jktho xk¡/h       Education) at the Central and State level and with UNICEF, the
